message.content:
Adults in Swaziland face several significant challenges. One of the biggest challenges is poverty, as a large portion of the population lives below the national poverty line. This often leads to limited access to basic necessities like food, clean water, and healthcare. High unemployment rates further exacerbate the economic struggles faced by adults.

Another major challenge is the prevalence of HIV/AIDS. Swaziland has one of the highest HIV prevalence rates globally, and adults are particularly impacted by this epidemic. It affects individuals' health and well-being, disrupts families, and often leads to increased caregiving responsibilities for those affected.

The limited access to quality education and skills training is also a prominent challenge. Many adults did not have the opportunity to receive a good education, which restricts their employment prospects and hampers economic growth. Lack of skills and vocational training programs further limit their ability to find suitable employment or start businesses.

Gender inequality is another significant challenge faced by adults in Swaziland. Women often face discrimination in various sectors such as employment, education, and legal rights. This restricts their opportunities and hinders progress towards gender equality and women empowerment.

Lastly, adults in Swaziland also face challenges related to political rights and freedom of expression. The country has a monarchy-based system, limiting political participation and dissent. This lack of political freedom can impact adults' ability to voice their concerns, influence policies, and participate in the governance of their country.
